Immunological processes play a critical role in spinal cord injury (SCI) and have a significant impact on the injury outcome and subsequent recovery. SCI triggers a complex cascade of inflammatory responses that involve various immune cells, cytokines, and chemokines. Understanding the immunological aspects of SCI is crucial for developing targeted therapeutic strategies to minimize secondary damage and promote neuroprotection and tissue repair.

Following the primary mechanical injury to the spinal cord, an inflammatory response is rapidly initiated. This acute inflammatory phase involves the activation of resident immune cells, such as microglia and astrocytes, as well as the infiltration of peripheral immune cells, including monocytes, neutrophils, and lymphocytes, into the injury site. These immune cells release pro-inflammatory cytokines, such as tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-α), interleukin-1 beta (IL-1β), and interleukin-6 (IL-6), which contribute to tissue damage and cell death.

Monocytes and macrophages are key players in the immune response after SCI. Monocytes are recruited to the injury site, where they differentiate into macrophages and assume distinct phenotypes depending on the microenvironment. The classical M1 macrophages exhibit pro-inflammatory properties and release cytotoxic molecules, exacerbating tissue damage. In contrast, the alternative M2 macrophages have anti-inflammatory and tissue-repairing characteristics, promoting axonal regeneration and modulating the immune response.

Studies have shown that manipulating the balance between M1 and M2 macrophages can influence the injury outcome. Strategies that promote a shift towards the M2 phenotype, such as administration of anti-inflammatory cytokines or transplantation of M2-polarized macrophages, have been shown to improve functional recovery and tissue repair in experimental models of SCI.

In addition to macrophages, T cells also play a crucial role in the immune response following SCI. T cells infiltrate the injured spinal cord and contribute to the secondary tissue damage through the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines. However, they can also have neuroprotective effects by producing anti-inflammatory cytokines and promoting tissue repair. The balance between pro-inflammatory T helper 1 (Th1) cells and anti-inflammatory T helper 2 (Th2) cells is crucial for the immune response and functional recovery after SCI.

The activation and regulation of immune cells after SCI are complex processes involving the interplay of various signaling molecules and immune modulators. Cytokines, chemokines, and growth factors released by immune cells and injured tissues influence the recruitment, activation, and polarization of immune cells. For example, chemokines such as monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1) and stromal cell-derived factor-1 (SDF-1) play important roles in attracting monocytes and lymphocytes to the injury site.

Furthermore, emerging evidence suggests that immunomodulatory approaches, such as immunosuppression or immunomodulation, can have therapeutic potential in SCI. For instance, administration of immunosuppressive drugs or antibodies targeting specific immune cells or cytokines has shown promise in reducing inflammation, improving tissue preservation, and enhancing functional recovery in preclinical models of SCI.

Moreover, recent advances in the field of immunotherapy have opened new avenues for SCI treatment. Approaches such as cell-based therapies, including mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) and immune cell transplantation, hold promise for promoting tissue repair and modulating the immune response. MSCs have immunomodulatory properties and can suppress inflammation, promote tissue regeneration, and enhance functional recovery in SCI models.

In summary, immunological processes play a crucial role in the pathophysiology of SCI. The dynamic interplay between immune cells, cytokines, and chemokines determines the outcome of the injury [@heller2021].
